Soils hold the largest C pools, and reforested areas, especially on historically cultivated lands, are storing significant C, though they haven't reached their full potential. Reforestation provides multi-decadal benefits by increasing C storage in biomass and soils, varying by region. A targeted, phased reforestation approach can improve C sequestration for decades to centuries, making it essential to expand reforestation efforts to maintain ecosystem functions and combat CO2 pollution.
metaDescription: Reforestation boosts carbon storage in U.S. soil and biomass, helping climate action.  With focus it can increase C storage and support ecosystem services (Nave et al).

title: The momentum of the solar energy transition
organization: Department of Geography, University of Exeter
keyFindings: Global decarbonization efforts require zero-carbon energy by 2050 or 2060. Solar energy, the most abundant source, may have passed a tipping point to dominate global electricity markets due to past policies. Challenges remain in grid stability, financing, supply chains, and political resistance. Addressing these barriers could accelerate the clean energy transition.
metaDescription: Global decarbonization needs zero-carbon energy by 2050, with solar leading. Issues include grid stability, funding, supply chains, and political pushback (Nijsse et al).

title: Mapping the irrecoverable carbon in Earth’s ecosystems
keyFindings: Rapid decarbonization and ecosystem protection are essential to avoid catastrophic climate change. Irrecoverable carbon, stored in ecosystems like peatlands, mangroves, and old-growth forests, cannot be restored by mid-century if lost. Since 2010, 4.0 Gt of irrecoverable carbon has been released, with 139.1 Gt at risk. Protecting key areas, including those managed by Indigenous communities, is crucial for climate security, as half of this carbon is concentrated in just 3.3% of Earth's land.
metaDescription: Fast decarbonization and protecting irrecoverable carbon are key to avoiding climate disaster with half in just 3.3% of Earth's land (Noon et al).

authors: National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine
title: Negative Emissions Technologies and Reliable Sequestration: A Research Agenda
author1: National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine
journal: National Academies of Sciences, Engineering & Medicine
keyFindings: As CO2 levels rise, policymakers are focusing on reducing emissions and removing CO2 from the atmosphere. This report examines methods to create or enhance carbon sinks in land and coastal areas. Storing CO2 in these reservoirs reduces atmospheric CO2, helping mitigate climate change, similar to emission prevention. Enhancing carbon sinks should be part of net emissions reduction strategies. Removing CO2 from the atmosphere has the same climate benefit as preventing the emission of an equivalent amount of CO2.
metaDescription: As CO2 levels rise, enhancing land and coastal carbon sinks reduce atmospheric CO2 offering the same climate benefit as preventing equivalent emissions.

title: Effective Coverage Targets for Ocean Protection
keyFindings: The UN’s 10% marine protected areas (MPA) target by 2020 is insufficient to protect biodiversity and achieve environmental or socioeconomic goals. A review of 144 studies suggests that 21-30% of the sea should be protected, with an average recommendation of 37%. Only 3% of objectives were met with ≤10% coverage, but 81% were achieved with over 50% protected.
metaDescription: The UN's 10% MPA target is insufficient for biodiversity and socioeconomic goals. Studies suggest 21-30% sea protection with an average of 37% (O'Leary et al).

title: Crediting agricultural soil carbon sequestration
keyFindings: The voluntary carbon market is expanding, with protocols to pay farmers for sequestering carbon in agricultural soils. A review of 12 soil organic carbon (SOC) MRV protocols reveals key differences in measuring SOC, GHG reductions, and addressing accounting issues like additionality and permanence. These variations risk creating nonequivalent credits, undermining program integrity. A regionally consistent framework is suggested to ensure transparent, robust, and standardized SOC credit generation.
metaDescription: The expanding carbon market pays farmers for soil carbon capture, but gaps in soil organic carbon measurement and accounting threaten credit reliability (Oldfield et al).

title: Climate Change and Land, Chapter 4: Land Degradation
keyFindings: This study explores how climate change and land degradation interact, focusing on non-drylands. It reviews land degradation processes, trends, and future projections, assessing how climate mitigation efforts, like bioenergy and carbon dioxide removal, impact land degradation. The chapter also evaluates how land degradation influences climate and affects human and natural systems. Sustainable land management practices—avoiding, reducing, and reversing degradation—are proposed, with eight case studies illustrating successful interventions. It concludes by identifying critical knowledge gaps and areas for further research, emphasizing the long-standing relationship between agriculture, land use, and environmental impacts.
metaDescription: This study looks at climate change impacts on non-dryland degradation, mitigation efforts and land management practices to avoid, reduce or reverse damage (Olsson et al).

title: Anthropogenic climate change has slowed global agricultural productivity growth
organization: Charles H. Dyson School of Applied Economics and Management, Cornell University
keyFindings: Agricultural productivity growth has been impacted by anthropogenic climate change (ACC). Using an econometric model, the study shows ACC reduced global agricultural total factor productivity (TFP) by 21% since 1961, equivalent to losing seven years of growth. Warmer regions like Africa and Latin America experienced even greater reductions (26–34%), highlighting increased vulnerability to climate change.
metaDescription: Climate change cut global farm productivity by 21% since 1961, with losses up to 34% in warmer areas like Africa and Latin America, raising vulnerability (Ortiz-Bobea et al).

title: Soil Health and Organic Farming: Water Management and Water Quality
keyFindings: Effective water management is vital in agriculture to handle both scarcity and excess. Inadequate water leads to crop failure; over-irrigation depletes aquifers and degrades soils. Excess moisture can cause nutrient loss, runoff, and greenhouse gas emissions. Organic practices like cover cropping and compost enhance soil health, improve water infiltration, and boost drought resilience. Research confirms organic systems retain more moisture and improve yields in drought. Climate extremes, such as California’s droughts and floods, highlight the need for resilient, soil-focused strategies. Integrated water and nutrient management reduces pollution and sustains soil life—key for long-term agricultural sustainability.
metaDescription: Efficient water use and healthy soils are key to farm resilience. Organic practices boost drought tolerance, reduce runoff, and protect yields (Ory et al).

title: Tick-borne disease risk in a forest food web
keyFindings: This study investigates the ecological drivers of zoonotic disease risk, particularly Lyme disease, using 19 years of data from southeastern New York. The abundance of acorns and rodents, alongside predator diversity and forest cover, significantly influences tick infection rates. Acorn-driven rodent increases boost tick populations, while diverse predators, especially bobcats, reduce pathogen prevalence. Climate conditions like warm, dry winters further reduce infected tick density. The study underscores the importance of both bottom-up (food resources) and top-down (predation) ecological interactions in managing tick-borne diseases and highlights ecological indicators for disease prevention.
metaDescription: Acorn abundance, rodent numbers, predator diversity and climate are linked to tick-borne disease risk, stressing bottom-up and top-down ecological drivers (Ostfeld et al).

title: Investment case for ecological farming
keyFindings: Ecological and regenerative farming presents a compelling investment opportunity by mitigating risks inherent in industrial agriculture, such as volatile input costs, soil degradation, climate vulnerability, and shifting consumer trends. Proven ecological systems—like holistic grazing, no-till cropping, and agroforestry—enhance natural capital, increase resilience, and improve profitability with lower volatility. These systems sequester carbon, align with climate policies, and access premium markets. Investors can capitalize on land regeneration and sustainable food production by backing skilled operators or forming partnerships. Scaling ecological farming offers superior risk-adjusted returns while delivering positive environmental impacts, making it a strategic choice for sustainable investment.
metaDescription: Ecological farming boosts resilience, cuts costs, restores land, and offers high returns, aligning with climate goals and shifting consumer demand (P. McMahon).

title: Privately protected areas increase global protected area coverage and connectivity
keyFindings: This study assesses the role of privately protected areas (PPAs) in conservation across 15 countries. PPAs are more likely to be in under-protected biomes and areas of high human disturbance, protect 1.2% more key biodiversity areas, account for 3.4% of protected land, and increase network connectivity by 7.05%. The findings highlight PPAs' unique contributions to biodiversity conservation and the need for greater recognition and support for their effective management.
metaDescription: Privately protected areas help conservation by protecting marginalized biomes, key biodiversity areas, and improving connectivity (Palfrey et al).

title: Carbon storage estimation in a secondary tropical forest at CIEE Sustainability Center, Monteverde, Costa Rica
keyFindings: A study in Monteverde, Costa Rica, evaluated carbon sequestration in a 50-hectare secondary growth tropical rainforest as part of a Carbon Neutrality Program. The forest, aged around 50 years, is located at 1100 m elevation. Two 1-hectare plots were sampled, measuring trees with a diameter ≥10 cm. The estimated total CO2 sequestered by the forest was 18,210 tons in 2019, highlighting its role as a significant carbon sink.
metaDescription: A 50-hectare secondary rainforest in Monteverde, Costa Rica sequestered 18,210 tons of CO2 in 2019 highlighting it as a significant carbon sink (Paniagua-Ramierez et al).

title: Keeping global warming within 1.5 °C constrains emergence of aridification
organization: School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Southern University of Science and Technology
keyFindings: This study estimates the Time of Emergence for Aridification (ToEA) using 27 climate models under RCP4.5 and RCP8.5. Aridification is projected to affect 32% (RCP4.5) and 24% (RCP8.5) of land before a 2°C global temperature rise. Limiting warming to 1.5°C could prevent aridification in two-thirds of affected regions, emphasizing the importance of early climate action to reduce widespread aridification and its impacts.
metaDescription: Aridification will impact 32% (RCP4.5) and 24% (RCP8.5) of land before 2°C warming. Keeping warming to 1.5°C prevents it in two-thirds of affected regions (Park et al).

title: The ‘Push–Pull’ Farming System: Climate-smart, sustainable agriculture for Africa (PDF)
journal: The International Centre of Insect Physiology and Ecology
keyFindings: The push–pull technology has helped nearly 97,000 cereal-livestock farmers in Africa address critical issues such as poor soils, pests, the parasitic weed *Striga hermonthica*, and fodder shortages. Developed by icipe and partners, this holistic, science-based approach has significantly improved rural livelihoods. In 2011, a climate-smart variant using drought-tolerant plants was introduced, expanding its application to drier regions and crops like sorghum. Push–pull’s success has been widely documented and it aims to secure food for one million people in East Africa by 2020, supporting a sustainable green revolution.
metaDescription: Push–pull has helped 97,000 African farmers tackle poor soils, pests, Striga and fodder shortages. It now covers dry areas and sorghum to feed one million (Parrott & Brock).

title: Diverse values of nature for sustainability
organization: Scientific Campus of the University of the Basque Country
keyFindings: Despite 25 years of progress in valuing ecosystem services, barriers like legal norms and market-driven policies still limit the inclusion of nature’s diverse values in decision-making. The Intergovernmental Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (IPBES) assessed over 50,000 sources, proposing value-centered approaches to better integrate nature’s values. Addressing this "values crisis" is key to tackling biodiversity loss, climate change, and social injustices. These approaches aim to drive transformative changes for more just and sustainable futures, aligning with global agreements like the Kunming-Montreal Biodiversity Framework and UN Sustainable Development Goals.
metaDescription: Despite efforts, legal norms and market-focused policies limit valuing nature’s roles. IPBES suggests value-based approaches for fair, sustainable futures (Pascual et al).

title: Climate-smart soils
keyFindings: Soils play a crucial role in ecosystem function and food production, with significant potential to mitigate greenhouse gas emissions. Although proven soil-based practices exist, their implementation is still limited, and accurate emission quantification remains challenging. Advances in research and technology offer opportunities for better integration of soils into climate policies. This study reviews current soil-based greenhouse gas research, summarizes mitigation practices, highlights data gaps, and suggests improvements through research and collaboration.
metaDescription: Soils are key for ecosystem function and greenhouse gas mitigation, with challenges in quantifying emissions (Paustian et al).

title: Quantifying carbon for agricultural soil management: from the current status toward a global soil information system
organization: Department of Soil and Crop Science, Colorado State University
keyFindings: Building and maintaining soil carbon is crucial for soil health and CO2 mitigation. Reliable and cost-effective methods to quantify soil carbon stock changes and forecast responses to management, climate, and soil conditions are essential. While technology for soil carbon measurement exists, challenges like spatial variability and high costs persist. Models offer a practical solution for carbon quantification, supporting climate policies in countries like Australia and Canada. A global soil information system is proposed, integrating data-model frameworks, remote sensing, and crowd-sourced data to improve carbon sequestration efforts.
metaDescription: Soil carbon is key for soil health and CO2 mitigation. Reliable, cost-effective methods and models aid policies for carbon capture globally (Paustian et al).

title: Cryosphere1.5°: Where Urgency and Ambition Meet
keyFindings: Governments must decide whether to take action to limit global warming to 1.5°C or risk exceeding it. Current Nationally Determined Contributions could lead to 3-4°C warming by the end of the century. The cryosphere—glaciers, snow, permafrost, and sea ice—is particularly sensitive to warming, and once temperatures exceed 1.5°C, irreversible changes will occur, leading to long-term impacts on sea levels and ecosystems. The report emphasizes that pathways to reduce emissions exist and urges immediate action to avoid catastrophic cryosphere-related climate change.
metaDescription: Governments must act to limit warming to 1.5°C or face 3-4°C by century's end. Cryosphere change will be irreversible, impacting sea levels and ecosystems (Pearson et al).

title: Climate–land-use interactions shape tropical mountain biodiversity and ecosystem functions
organization: Department of Animal Ecology and Tropical Biology, Biocenter, University of Würzburg
keyFindings: Interactions between climate and land use explained—on average—54% of the variation in species richness, species composition and ecosystem functions, whereas only 30% of variation was related to single drivers. This study reveals that climate can modulate the effects of land use on biodiversity and ecosystem functioning, and points to a lowered resistance of ecosystems in climatically challenging environments to ongoing land-use changes in tropical mountainous regions.
metaDescription: Climate and land use interactions explained 54% of ecosystem variation, single drivers 30%. Climate shapes land-use effects, lowering resilience in tropical mountains (Peters et al).

title: Large conservation gains possible for global biodiversity facets
keyFindings: This study emphasizes the importance of protecting multiple facets of biodiversity—species, functional, and phylogenetic diversity—in birds and mammals. It shows that a 5% increase in protected land could significantly expand the protection of these biodiversity facets. However, conservation outcomes depend on chosen strategies, with global biodiversity protection requiring more land than local diversity. The study highlights that species and phylogenetic priorities are more aligned than functional ones, especially in birds. It provides a framework and tools to link conservation objectives with biodiversity metrics for more effective multi-faceted biodiversity protection.
metaDescription: Protecting species and phylogenetic diversity requires a 5% protected land increase (Pollock et al).

title: Reducing food’s environmental impacts through producers and consumers
organization: Department of Zoology, University of Oxford
keyFindings: This study examines the environmental impacts of food production across 38,700 farms and 1,600 processors, packaging types, and retailers. It reveals a 50-fold variation in impacts among producers of the same product, highlighting significant mitigation opportunities. However, reducing impacts is complex due to trade-offs and supply chain interactions. Notably, even the lowest-impact animal products generally have higher environmental impacts than plant-based alternatives, emphasizing the need for dietary changes. The findings advocate for producers to monitor and report their impacts while adopting flexible practices to meet environmental goals.
metaDescription: Food impacts vary 50-fold among producers, with animal products exceeding plant-based ones. Monitoring and flexible practices are key to reducing impacts (Poore & Nemecek).

title: Diversity enhances carbon storage in tropical forests
organization: Forest Ecology and Forest Management Group, Wageningen University
keyFindings: Tropical forests store 25% of global carbon and contain 96% of the world's tree species, but it was unclear if biodiversity affects carbon storage. Using data from 144,000 trees across 2050 plots in the Neotropics, this study found that aboveground biomass (AGB) is mainly driven by rainfall, tree diameter, and species richness. Biodiversity positively impacts AGB, especially at smaller scales, highlighting its importance for ecosystem functioning. The results emphasize the need to include biodiversity conservation in the UN's strategy for reducing emissions from deforestation and degradation.
metaDescription: Tropical forest biodiversity enhances carbon storage. Protecting biodiversity is key to cutting deforestation emissions (Poorter et al).

title: Global maps of cropland extent and change show accelerated cropland expansion in the twenty-first century
organization: Department of Geographical Sciences, University of Maryland,
keyFindings: This study analyzes global cropland changes from 2003 to 2019 using satellite data. By 2019, cropland covered 1,244 Mha, with an annual net primary production (NPP) of 5.5 Pg C. Cropland area increased by 9% and NPP by 25%, driven mainly by expansion in Africa and South America. Half of the new cropland replaced natural vegetation, challenging ecosystem sustainability. Despite a 10% decrease in per-capita cropland area due to population growth, per-capita NPP rose by 3.5% through intensified agriculture. Provided is crucial data for tracking land use changes globally.
metaDescription: From 2003-2019 cropland grew 9% in Africa and South America, often replacing natural vegetation. Net primary production rose 3.5% through rigorous farming (Potapov et al).

title: Ecological consequences of forest elephant declines for Afrotropical forests
keyFindings: Poaching is rapidly driving African forest elephants (Loxodonta cyclotis) to extinction, leading to vast areas of tropical forest without their ecological influence. Elephants are crucial for seed dispersal, nutrient cycling, and herbivory. Their decline will favor abiotically dispersed tree species, increase tree density, and reduce large tree recruitment, affecting forest structure and carbon stocks. Central African forests will become more homogeneous and resemble Neotropical forests, where megafauna were lost long ago. Stopping poaching and integrating elephant habitats into land-use planning are vital for forest conservation and mitigating these cascading ecological effects.
metaDescription: Poaching of forest elephants disrupts seed dispersal, nutrient cycles, and causes denser forests, altered species mix, and lower carbon stocks (Poulsen et al).

title: Agro-ecological Europe: a desirable, credible option to address food and environmental challenges
keyFindings: Europe's agricultural system faces growing pressure to transition towards sustainability. Current diets, high in sugar, protein, and low in fruits and vegetables, contribute to health issues and food dependency on imports. The TYFA scenario proposes eliminating pesticides, promoting agro-ecological practices, and adopting healthier diets with fewer animal products. Despite a 35% drop in production, it meets food needs, reduces agricultural GHG emissions by 40%, and restores biodiversity. Extensified livestock grazing enhances soil fertility, biodiversity, and climate mitigation, playing a crucial role in this sustainable approach.
metaDescription: Europe's food transition, via the TYFA plan, cuts GHG by 40%, restores biodiversity, and meets food needs through agro-ecology and better diets (Poux & Aubert).

title: Overview chapter on soil degradation
organization: Sustainable Production, The New Zealand Institute for Plant and Food Research Limited
keyFindings: Soil degradation is accelerating globally due to human-driven factors, especially land mismanagement and overexploitation linked to population growth. Climate change, land-use shifts, and socio-political pressures create feedback loops that worsen degradation. Key processes include erosion, pollution, salinization, and biodiversity loss. The chapter outlines monitoring methods and innovative soil remediation strategies to restore land functionality.
metaDescription: Soil degradation is rising due to misuse, climate change, and pressures, with solutions in monitoring and innovative remediation strategies (Müller et al).

organization: Institute for Environmental Studies, Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam
keyFindings: Conservation agriculture (CA) is promoted as a sustainable practice to address issues like soil erosion, nutrient leaching, and water overuse in industrial farming. CA can also mitigate climate change by reducing greenhouse gas emissions and promoting sustainable soil and water use. However, the extent of CA adoption is uncertain. This study estimates that 9%-15% of global arable land is currently managed under CA, with future potential for up to 81% coverage. These estimates support ecosystem modeling and climate adaptation efforts, helping assess CA's realistic mitigation potential.
metaDescription: Conservation agriculture covers 9%-15% of global farmland tackles soil erosion, nutrient loss and climate change with potential to reach 81% in the future (Prestele et al).

title: Global Assessment of Agricultural System Redesign for Sustainable Intensification
keyFindings: Sustainable intensification (SI) of agriculture offers opportunities to enhance both agricultural productivity and natural capital. Efficiency and substitution help, but full system redesign is crucial as ecological and economic conditions shift. Analyzing 47 large-scale SI initiatives, the study estimates that 163M farms (29% globally) are practicing SI on 453M hectares (9% of global farmland). SI methods include integrated pest management, conservation agriculture, and irrigation management. While SI is making progress, challenges remain, such as scaling SI practices and creating agricultural knowledge economies. SI may be nearing a transformative tipping point.
metaDescription: Nearing a transformative point, sustainable intensification spans 163M farms and 453 Mha globally, using methods like conservation agriculture (Pretty et al).

title: Non-Flat Earth Recalibrated for Terrain and Topsoil
keyFindings: This study recalculates Earth's land surface from 15 Gha to over 64 Gha by accounting for topography, soil ruggedness, and micro-relief. Using satellite and LiDAR data, the study finds significant increases in surface area and soil organic carbon, estimating 8580 Gt SOC, much higher than current estimates. Global biomass and biodiversity are likely 2-3.5 times larger, and net primary productivity increases to over 270 Gt C/year. The findings highlight the importance of soil complexity and support the need for a "Soil Ecology Institute" to better understand land and carbon dynamics.
metaDescription: Earth expands from 15 Gha to 64 Gha accounting for topographyraising soil carbon to 8580 gigatons, increasing biomass, biodiversity and net productivity (R. Blakemore).

title: Impacts of climate change at 1.5C, 2C and beyond
keyFindings: Carbon Brief analyzed data from 70 climate studies to show how global warming will impact the world and its regions. The studies compare the effects of 1.5°C and 2°C warming, aligned with the Paris Agreement limits, and include projections for higher levels such as 2.5°C, 3°C, and 4°C. These findings highlight the escalating risks and impacts of rising global temperatures.
metaDescription: 70 climate studies were reviewed, comparing impacts of 1.5C to 4C warming above pre-industrial levels, highlighting rising risks worldwide (R. McSweeney).

title: Global Energy System Based on 100% Renewable Energy – Power Sector
organization: Centre for Environment and Energy Development
keyFindings: A global shift to 100% renewable electricity is feasible and more cost-effective than the current fossil fuel-based system, with political will as the key barrier. By 2050, renewable energy can meet global electricity demand, driven by solar PV (69%), wind (18%), and battery storage. The levelized cost of electricity will drop from 70 €/MWh in 2015 to 52 €/MWh by 2050. This transition reduces greenhouse gas emissions to zero and creates 36M jobs. Battery storage plays a critical role, covering 31% of demand. Renewable energy also significantly reduces energy losses compared to the current system.
metaDescription: A 100% renewable grid by 2050 is feasible, cheaper, and job-rich. Solar (69%), wind (18%), and storage (31%) cut emissions to zero. Key barrier: politics (Ram et al).

title: Matrix condition mediates the effects of habitat fragmentation on species extinction risk
organization: Natural Resources and Environmental Studies Institute, University of Northern British Columbia
keyFindings: Habitat loss drives global biodiversity decline, but human pressure in areas surrounding habitat fragments is less understood. This study analyzed 4,426 terrestrial mammals and found that fragmentation and matrix condition (human impact in surrounding areas) are stronger predictors of extinction risk than habitat loss alone. Fragmentation has greater importance than life-history traits or human pressure variables, and its impact intensifies with deteriorating matrix conditions. These results highlight the need for habitat matrix restoration as a key conservation strategy to mitigate the negative effects of fragmentation on biodiversity.
metaDescription: Fragmentation and matrix condition predict mammal extinction risk more than habitat loss. Restoring the habitat matrix is vital to protect biodiversity (Ramirez-Delgado et al).

title: Arctic has warmed nearly four times faster than the globe since 1979
keyFindings: Arctic warming, known as Arctic amplification, has accelerated much faster than the global average. This study reveals that over the last 43 years, the Arctic has warmed nearly four times faster than the rest of the world—higher than commonly reported. Comparing observations with climate models, the four-fold warming is a rare occurrence in simulations. While longer-term data shows more consistency between observations and models, uncertainties before 1979 hinder accurate comparisons. The findings suggest either the recent Arctic warming is an extremely rare event or that climate models may underestimate Arctic amplification.
metaDescription: Arctic warming is four times faster than global rates over 43 years. Models may underplay this amplification, stressing the need for improved simulations (Rantanen et al).

title: 2024: A decade of deforestation data
keyFindings: After 10 years and 1.3M data points tracking corporate exposure to tropical deforestation, the Forest 500 report highlights key lessons for accelerating deforestation action. Alarmingly, 23% of companies and financial institutions have yet to commit to deforestation policies. Major corporations like Deichmann, Bright Food, and Vanguard are among those ignoring the issue, despite strong progress made by front-runners like Nestlé. Financial institutions, however, lag behind, with none scoring above 50%. As the world nears 2030 deforestation targets, COP30 in 2025 is seen as a critical moment to drive substantial change before it’s too late.
metaDescription: 23% of companies lack deforestation policies. With COP30 nearing, urgent action is needed to meet 2030 targets and prevent irreversible damage (Thomson & Franklin).

title: Sustainable Development Report 2024The SDGs and the UN Summit of the Future
keyFindings: The UN Sustainable Development Solutions Network mobilizes global knowledge institutions to address critical sustainable development challenges, focusing on science, policy, and development. The 2024 Sustainable Development Report highlights key issues, including stagnant global progress on the SDGs since 2020, significant variation in SDG achievement by country, and the urgent need for reform in global financial systems. Critical areas such as food, land systems, and multilateralism are off-track, with significant global cooperation required for progress. The report suggests pathways for sustainable food and land systems, emphasizing dietary shifts and deforestation prevention.
metaDescription: The UN tackles sustainable development challenges. This report highlights slow SDG progress, financial reforms and solutions for food and land systems (G. Lafortune).

title: Climate change has likely already affected global food production
organization: Institute on the Environment (IonE), University of Minnesota
keyFindings: Climate change has already impacted global crop yields, with effects varying across regions and crops. Using weather and crop data, researchers found yield changes ranging from -13.4% (oil palm) to +3.5% (soybean). Europe, Southern Africa, and Australia experienced mostly negative effects, while Latin America saw positive outcomes. The study suggests a 1% global reduction in consumable food calories, with food insecurity worsened in nearly half of affected countries. This indicates that climate change is already affecting global food production.
metaDescription: Climate change is reducing global crop yields with impacts varying by region and crop, leading to a 1% drop in food calories and worsening food insecurity (Ray et al).

title: Improving climate and biodiversity outcomes through restoration of forest integrity
keyFindings: Restoring degraded areas within forests can enhance climate mitigation, biodiversity conservation, and resilience to climate change while reducing conflicts with agriculture. Current climate mitigation estimates may be low, as they focus on reforesting cleared land. By prioritizing the restoration of over 1.5B hectares of degraded forests, which retain 50-80% of their potential biomass, rapid biodiversity and climate benefits can be achieved. Targeting these interventions supports the 30x30 goal of the Convention on Biodiversity’s Global Biodiversity Framework.
metaDescription: Restoring degraded forests with 50-80% biomass can boost climate mitigation, biodiversity and resilience supporting the 30x30 Biodiversity Framework goal (Rayden et al).

title: Energy and Climate Outlook: Perspectives from 2015
keyFindings: The 2015 Energy and Climate Outlook provides an annual assessment of global trends in economic growth, resource use, and environmental impacts using the MIT Integrated Global Systems Model. It projects future energy, land, water, climate, and atmospheric conditions based on current policies, highlighting the need for additional measures to stabilize greenhouse gas levels. The scenario serves as a descriptive projection rather than a policy recommendation.
metaDescription: The 2015 Energy and Climate Outlook projects future energy, land, water, and climate trends, urging more policies to stabilize greenhouse gas levels (Reilly et al).

title: More than one quarter of Africa’s tree cover is found outside areas previously classified as forest
organization: Department of Geosciences and Natural Resource Management, University of Copenhagen
keyFindings: Monitoring trees inside and outside forests is crucial for sustainable land management, but current systems overlook non-forest trees or are too costly. Using PlanetScope nanosatellite data, researchers mapped tree cover across Africa in 2019, finding that 29% of tree cover exists outside traditional forest areas. This accurate, continent-wide mapping enables better understanding of tree-based ecosystems, improving land use assessments and supporting natural climate solutions.
metaDescription: PlanetScope data mapping shows 29% of Africa's tree cover is outside forests. Accurate tracking improves land use assessments and climate solutions (Reiner et al).

title: Shared Socio-Economic Pathways (SSPs): An Overview
keyFindings: Socio-economic scenarios are essential for developing emissions projections, climate change forecasts, and evaluating climate impacts and adaptation strategies. The outdated SRES scenarios have been replaced by new SSPs, which provide a framework of socio-economic pathways for mitigation and adaptation. SSPs include broad narratives on global future trends (population, GDP, urbanization) and serve as building blocks for integrated models. These models generate baseline and mitigation scenarios, aiding climate analysts in preparing policy analyses. SSPs aim to better integrate mitigation, adaptation, and climate impact research for future climate assessments.
metaDescription: SSPs replace old SRES, offering socio-economic paths for emissions, mitigation and adaptation. They integrate population, GDP, and urbanization (Riahi et al).

title: Implications of New Research for the IPCC 1.5C Special Report, with a Focus on Land Use
keyFindings: The review invites scientists to examine the IPCC Special Report on the 1.5°C target, focusing on land-use sector contributions. Key findings emphasize the potential of forest-sector mitigation through reforestation, ecosystem restoration, and improved management. Additionally, it highlights agriculture and indigenous land control as important elements of climate mitigation. The report suggests further research into synergies and trade-offs in land-use mitigation, critiques assumptions about BioEnergy Carbon Capture and Storage (BECCS), and encourages consideration of "non-overshoot" scenarios for long-term goals. Greater mitigation ambition is necessary by 2050 to address the Paris Agreement's ambition gap.
metaDescription: The review highlights forest restoration, agroecology and Indigenous land key for 1.5°C mitigation urging further research and greater ambition by 2050 (P. Riggs).

title: Four decades of Antarctic Ice Sheet mass balance from 1979–2017
organization: Department of Earth System Science, University of California
keyFindings: From 1979 to 2017, Antarctic Ice Sheet mass loss increased significantly, driven by the Amundsen/Bellingshausen Sea, Wilkes Land, and the West/Northeast Peninsula. Ice discharge data show mass loss rising from 40 Gt/y in 1979-1990 to 252 Gt/y in 2009-2017, contributing to 14.0 mm of sea-level rise since 1979. West Antarctica contributed the most, with East Antarctica playing a significant role. The mass loss is linked to warm circumpolar deep water melting ice shelves, destabilizing glaciers, and raising sea levels, driven by enhanced polar westerlies.
metaDescription: Antarctic mass loss surged from 1979-2017 driven by warm deep water melting ice shelves, raising sea levels by 14 mm in West and East Antarctica(Rignot et al).

title: Weaker land–climate feedbacks from nutrient uptake during photosynthesis-inactive periods
organization: Climate and Ecosystem Sciences Division, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory
keyFindings: Terrestrial carbon–climate feedbacks depend on soil decomposition and photosynthesis, tightly regulated by nutrients. Previous Earth system models poorly represented nutrient dynamics, leading to uncertainty in predictions. Using a new land model, researchers found that nutrient uptake, especially nitrogen and phosphorus, during non-photosynthesis periods plays a significant role, accounting for 45% and 43% of annual uptake, respectively. Ignoring this process in models results in large biases in nitrogen leaching (96%) and N2O emissions (44%), overestimating terrestrial feedbacks and reducing carbon sequestration predictions, thus affecting climate forecasts.
metaDescription: Terrestrial feedbacks rely on nutrient uptake with nitrogen and phosphorus uptake during non-photosynthesis times, affecting carbon storage predictions (Riley et al).

title: Rewiring the Carbon Cycle: A Theoretical Framework for Animal‐Driven Ecosystem Carbon Sequestration
organization: School of the Environment, Yale University
keyFindings: Most carbon cycle models overlook animal-mediated effects, focusing on plants, microbes, and the atmosphere. However, growing evidence shows animals significantly influence carbon cycling, leading to misrepresentation in models. A new framework integrating animals into carbon flux and storage models reveals that animals alter carbon storage pathways through both direct consumption and indirect nutrient recycling. This enhances carbon capture and storage in ecosystems. The study suggests animals play a larger role in the carbon cycle than previously recognized, highlighting their potential in nature-based climate solutions to mitigate climate change.
metaDescription: Carbon models ignore animal roles but new research shows they help carbon storage via nutrient recycling, highlighting their potential in climate solutions (Rizzuto et al).

title: Marine reserves can mitigate and promote adaptation to climate change
keyFindings: Significant greenhouse gas reductions are necessary to meet the Paris Agreement targets, but additional steps are needed to protect ecosystems and biodiversity. Well-managed marine reserves can help marine ecosystems and humans adapt to climate change impacts, such as acidification, sea-level rise, storms, species shifts, and reduced productivity. Marine reserves promote carbon sequestration and buffer against environmental fluctuations and extreme events. They are a cost-effective, low-tech adaptation strategy, offering multiple co-benefits at local and global scales, improving resilience for both ecosystems and human populations.
metaDescription: Marine reserves help ecosystems adapt to climate change boosting resilience carbon storage and offering low-cost defense from acidification and rising seas (Roberts et al).

title: 30×30: A Blueprint For Ocean Protection
keyFindings: Covering 43% of Earth and 70% of its living space, the high seas play a vital role in carbon storage via the ocean's biological pump. Facing threats from exploitation, pollution, and climate change, these ecosystems urgently need protection. Scientists propose safeguarding 30% of high seas through a resilient, data-informed marine sanctuary network. This ecologically feasible approach, avoiding key fishing zones and proposing a mining moratorium, hinges solely on securing global political commitment.
metaDescription: High seas store carbon, face rising threats, and need urgent protection—scientists urge 30% to be conserved via a global, data-driven sanctuary plan (O'Leary et al).

title: Nature’s Strongholds
keyFindings: The 2022 Global Biodiversity Framework (GBF) emphasizes area-based conservation to meet the target of conserving 30% of global land by 2030. This essay highlights "Nature's Strongholds"—extensive, interconnected, high-integrity areas that are effectively managed and equitably governed—as key to achieving this goal. Examples include the Congo and Amazon basins. Scaling up conservation of these strongholds is essential to address global biodiversity threats.
metaDescription: The Global Biodiversity Framework stresses conserving 30% of land by 2030 through large interconnected well-managed areas like the Congo and Amazon basins (Robinson et al).

title: Planetary commons: A new paradigm for safeguarding Earth-regulating systems in the Anthropocene
organization: Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research
keyFindings: The Anthropocene marks a shift from Holocene stability to a path with rising risks of irreversible changes in Earth's systems. To manage these risks, a new global approach is needed beyond the current global commons framework, which focuses on shared resources. The proposed "planetary commons" framework would govern not only shared regions but also critical biophysical systems vital for Earth’s resilience. This approach aims to enhance stewardship obligations and strengthen planetary resilience and justice, ensuring sustainable management of Earth's life-support systems regardless of national borders.
metaDescription: The Anthropocene demands a new "planetary commons" to govern Earth's vital systems enhancing resilience justice and global stewardship (Rockstrom et al).

title: A roadmap for rapid decarbonization
keyFindings: The Paris Agreement aligns with scientific goals but faces inconsistencies between targets and national commitments. Political short-termism often hinders long-term progress despite some countries' mid-century decarbonization strategies. Current models struggle to capture rapid change and innovation, as seen in China's recent shift in coal use. To address this, a "carbon law" is proposed, aiming to halve CO2 emissions every decade. Combined with scalable carbon removal and land-use emission reductions, this approach could achieve net-zero emissions by mid-century, essential for limiting global warming to below 2°C.
metaDescription: The Paris goals need a "carbon law" to halve CO2 every decade for net-zero by mid-century ensuring warming stays below 2°C (Rockstrom et al).

title: Importance of forest structure for carbon fluxes of the Amazon rainforest
keyFindings: Assessing forest productivity, biomass, and structure is crucial for understanding tropical ecosystem responses to climate and human impacts. Researchers used space-borne LIDAR to simulate carbon dynamics in the Amazon, encompassing 410B trees over 7.8M km². The forest serves as a carbon sink, sequestering 0.56 GtC annually, with a gross primary productivity (GPP) of 25.1 tC ha⁻¹ a⁻¹ and woody net primary productivity (wANPP) of 4.2 tC ha⁻¹ a⁻¹. Forest structure and successional states notably affect productivity and biomass, emphasizing their importance in accurate carbon budget assessments and climate change analyses.
metaDescription: The Amazon study using LIDAR shows it as a carbon sink storing 0.56 GtC/year with GPP of 25.1 tC/ha/a and highlights the structure's role in output (Rödig et al).

title: Land based measures to mitigate climate change: Potential and feasibility by country
organization: Department of Environmental Sciences, University of Virginia
keyFindings: Land-based climate mitigation measures are crucial for meeting global climate goals, with potential ranging from 8–13.8 GtCO2eq per year by 2050. Analyzing 20 measures across 200+ countries, the study finds that cost-effective potential (up to $100/tCO2eq) covers 40% of the technical potential, aligning with a 1.5°C pathway. Forests and ecosystems contribute 50%, agriculture 35%, and demand-side measures 15%. Mitigation potential varies significantly by region, with 80% located in developing countries facing feasibility challenges due to governance, investment, and socio-cultural barriers. Overcoming these barriers through targeted investments could unlock significant, low-cost climate benefits and co-benefits for adaptation.
metaDescription: Land-based mitigation can cut 8–13.8 GtCO2eq/yr by 2050 with 50% from forests 35% agriculture 15% demand measures mainly in developing nations (Roe et al).

title: Contribution of the land sector to a 1.5°C world
organization: Department of Environmental Sciences, University of Virginia
keyFindings: The Paris Agreement aims to limit warming to 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels. Achieving this target will require transforming the land sector, focusing on agriculture, forestry, wetlands, and bioenergy. These measures could feasibly contribute 30% (15 GtCO2e/year) of the needed global mitigation by 2050. However, meeting the 1.5°C goal demands more effort than the 2°C target, necessitating risk management, barrier reduction, and incentives. Scaling up mitigation must also ensure sustainable development, food security, and environmental benefits. The roadmap highlights priority measures and regions to guide land-sector efforts toward the 1.5°C target.
metaDescription: The 1.5°C goal needs land-sector efforts in agriculture forestry wetlands bioenergy for 30% of 2050 mitigation with risks barriers and incentives addressed (Roe et al).

title: Scenarios towards limiting global mean temperature increase below 1.5 °C
organization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis
keyFindings: The 2015 Paris Agreement aims to limit global warming to 1.5°C by 2100. Scenarios achieving this goal require keeping end-of-century radiative forcing below 1.9 W/m². Using six integrated assessment models and a simple climate model, the study explored different socio-economic, technological, and resource assumptions from five Shared Socio-economic Pathways (SSPs). Achieving 1.5°C requires a rapid shift to low-carbon energy, reduced energy use, and carbon-dioxide removal. However, some SSPs, particularly those with high inequalities, heavy fossil-fuel reliance, or inconsistent climate policies, struggle to meet the target. Further research is needed to guide policy-makers on implementing feasible pathways.
metaDescription: Achieving the 1.5°C Paris goal needs rapid low-carbon shifts reduced energy use and CO2 removal some socio-economic scenarios face barriers with goal (Rogelj et al).

title: Chapter 2: Mitigation pathways compatible with 1.5C in the context of sustainable development
keyFindings: This chapter reviews pathways to limit global warming to 1.5°C, exploring emissions roles, overshoot scenarios, and impacts on energy, land use, and sustainable development. Achieving this goal requires rapid CO2 cuts, reaching net zero by 2050, with deep non-CO2 reductions. Successful pathways involve transitioning to low-carbon energy, land management, and carbon dioxide removal (CDR). High inequality, strong fossil fuel reliance, or weak policies hinder progress. Pathways rely on increased investments, energy shifts, and lifestyle changes. Uncertainties remain, including CDR's effectiveness and rapid technology changes, affecting 1.5°C strategies. Global cooperation and ambitious policy efforts are essential.
metaDescription: Reaching 1.5°C needs swift CO2 cuts net zero by 2050 low-carbon shifts CDR lifestyle changes strong policies global action and investments (Rogelj et al).

title: Using ecosystem integrity to maximize climate mitigation and minimize risk in international forest policy
journal: Frontiers in Forests and Global Change
keyFindings: International policies like the Paris Agreement and the Convention on Biological Diversity address forests but often treat all forest types equally, limiting policy effectiveness. This study proposes using an ecosystem integrity framework to guide policies, highlighting that primary forests exhibit higher integrity and lower risk than human-modified forests. Protecting primary forests, developing large-scale data to identify high-integrity areas, and implementing the ecosystem integrity framework can optimize long-term carbon storage and ecosystem services. This approach could better align forest policies with biodiversity and climate goals, addressing the intersecting crises more effectively.
metaDescription: Primary forests show higher integrity and lower risk policies must protect them use data to guide carbon storage and ecosystem service optimization (Rogers et al).

title: Closing the yield gap while ensuring water sustainability
keyFindings: Water scarcity limits crop production globally, and irrigation boosts yields but is constrained by freshwater availability. Innovations have increased agricultural water withdrawals, pressuring environmental flows. This study assesses global water use for crop production under current and maximum yield scenarios. Results suggest irrigation could sustainably increase by 48% (408 km³/yr), expanding to 26% of rainfed lands, adding 37% more calories—enough to feed 2.8B people. Eliminating unsustainable practices could still allow a 24% increase in calorie production. Sustainable irrigation expansion could significantly enhance food security while maintaining environmental balance in the coming decades.
metaDescription: Irrigation could increase 48% expanding to 26% of rainfed lands boosting food by 37% while supporting sustainability and addressing water scarcity (Rosa et al).

title: Multiscale Scenarios for Nature Futures
organization: German Centre for Integrative Biodiversity Research
keyFindings: Human development and nature conservation are interconnected, yet current scenarios fail to explicitly address this link. This study proposes a strategy to create scenarios focused on our relationship with nature to guide decision-making across different scales. The approach aims to integrate human and environmental targets, providing a more comprehensive framework for sustainable development planning. These nature-centered scenarios will help align policy and action with both human well-being and ecosystem health, supporting more holistic decision-making processes.
metaDescription: Linking human development and nature goals needs scenarios that focus on our relationship with nature to guide decisions at multiple scales (Rosa et al).

title: Early season plant cover supports more effective pest control than insecticide applications
organization: Department of Entomology, Pennsylvania State University
keyFindings: Conservation practices like no-till and cover crops support arthropod predators, protecting crops. Despite increased adoption, many farmers still use insecticides, including neonicotinoid seed coatings, which can disrupt biological control by harming beneficial arthropods. In a 3-year corn-soy rotation, the study compared preventive pest management (PPM) and integrated pest management (IPM) with and without cover crops. Results showed that early-season vegetative cover reduced pest density and damage by increasing predator abundance. PPM reduced predation compared to no management, while IPM disrupted predator communities due to pyrethroid toxicity. Promoting cover crops and minimizing broad-spectrum insecticides offers the best pest management outcomes.
metaDescription: Cover crops boost pest control by supporting predators; using fewer insecticides and avoiding broad-spectrum types can improve conservation outcomes (Rowen et al).

title: Reconciling Conservation and Global Biodiversity Goals with Community Land Rights in Asia
keyFindings: The 15th Conference of the Parties aims to adopt a Global Biodiversity Framework, including the 30x30 goal to protect 30% of land and water by 2030. However, concerns arise over human rights impacts on Indigenous and local communities whose territories often overlap with these areas. The report emphasizes recognizing the conservation role of these communities, managing territories holding 36% of intact forests and 80% of global biodiversity. Conservation efforts, rooted in ancestral knowledge, outmatch state-managed lands in biodiversity and carbon storage. This calls for ending exclusionary approaches, securing land rights, and prioritizing Indigenous-led governance to address climate and biodiversity crises.
metaDescription: COP15's goal sparks human rights concerns prioritizing Indigenous-led conservation, securing land rights and ending exclusionary approaches which is vital (Asia Indigenous Peoples Pact et al).

title: 4p1000 initiative: Opportunities, limitations and challenges for implementing soil organic carbon sequestration as a sustainable development strategy
organization: CNRS, Institute for Ecology and Environmental Sciences
keyFindings: The "4 per 1000" Initiative promotes climate change adaptation, mitigation, and food security by enhancing soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration through sustainable land management. It aims to increase SOC stocks by 0.4% annually to counteract atmospheric CO2 growth. The Initiative's scientific committee focuses on identifying indicators, research priorities, and region-specific practices. While SOC sequestration helps offset greenhouse gas emissions, its main benefits lie in improved soil quality and climate adaptation. The Initiative is a collaborative platform for policymakers, scientists, and stakeholders. Challenges include vague targets, barriers to increasing SOC, and the need for multi-party cooperation to drive agricultural sustainability.
metaDescription: The "4 per 1000" Initiative aims to boost soil organic carbon for climate adaptation, mitigation and food security through sustainable land practices (Rumpel et al).

title: Long-term climate change mitigation potentias with organic matter management on grasslands
organization: Department of Environmental Science, Policy, and Management, University of California
keyFindings: Compost amendments to grasslands show potential for climate change mitigation through carbon (C) sequestration but also result in increased greenhouse gas emissions, particularly nitrous oxide (N2O). Using the DAYCENT model, researchers found that compost application led to long-term net greenhouse gas sinks. Lower C:N compost increased carbon storage but elevated N2O emissions, while smaller, repeated applications reduced N2O fluxes. Over 10 years, mitigation potential ranged from 130 to 158 g CO2-eq·m²·yr⁻¹, and over 30 years, 63 to 84 g CO2-eq·m²·yr⁻¹. These findings highlight a trade-off between maximizing C sequestration and minimizing N2O emissions.
metaDescription: Compost amendments to grasslands increase carbon sequestration but also raise N2O emissions highlighting a trade-off in climate change mitigation potential (Ryals et al).

title: Impacts of organic matter amendments on carbon and nitrogen dynamics in grassland soils
organization: Department of Environmental Science, Policy, and Management, University of California
keyFindings: A single compost application to grassland soils significantly increased soil carbon (C) and nitrogen (N) storage in labile and protected pools over three years, with stronger effects in inland valley grasslands than coastal areas. Compost was incorporated into the free and occluded light soil fractions, enhancing C and N retention. The amendment shifted soil organic matter composition, showing an increase in functional groups indicative of organic matter decomposition. These results suggest compost can boost soil C and N storage in grasslands, offering a potential strategy for climate change mitigation.
metaDescription: Compost boosts soil carbon and nitrogen storage in grasslands enhancing labile and protected pools showing potential for climate change mitigation (Ryals et al).

title: European primary forest database v2.0
organization: German Centre for Integrative Biodiversity Research
keyFindings: This study provides a comprehensive geodatabase and map of Europe's remaining primary forests, which are scarce and continue to disappear. It compiles data from 18,411 patches (41.1 Mha) across 33 countries, with information on location, naturalness, and tree species. Satellite data (1985–2018) confirmed 94% of these patches have been undisturbed in the last 30 years. This dataset aims to support ecological research and conservation planning for preserving Europe's primary forests.
metaDescription: A comprehensive dataset of Europe's 18,411 primary forest patches shows 94% undisturbed in 30 years aiding ecological research and conservation efforts (Sabatini et al).

title: Protecting the global ocean for biodiversity, food and climate
keyFindings: This study develops a conservation planning framework to prioritize Marine Protected Areas that maximize biodiversity protection, fisheries yield, and marine carbon stock preservation. Currently, only 2.7% of the ocean is highly protected, mainly due to conflicts with fisheries. The framework shows that coordinated global efforts could double the efficiency of ocean conservation, helping coastal nations achieve biodiversity, food security, and climate action goals. This flexible approach can inform both national marine plans and global conservation strategies for future sustainability.
metaDescription: Marine protected areas protect biodiversity boost fisheries yield, and secure marine carbon with coordinated global efforts doubling efficiency (Sala et al).

title:
No-take marine reserves are the most effective protected areas
in the ocean
keyFindings: Marine protected areas (MPAs), especially no-take marine reserves, are highly effective in restoring biodiversity and enhancing ecosystem resilience. A meta-analysis reveals fish biomass in marine reserves is 670% greater than in unprotected areas and 343% higher than in partially protected MPAs. These reserves promote ecosystem complexity and resilience through trophic cascades. While not immune to climate change, marine reserves offer better protection than unprotected areas and benefit local fisheries and ecotourism by creating jobs and income opportunities.
metaDescription: No-take marine reserves restore biodiversity, raise fish biomass 670% over unprotected areas, boost resilience and aid fisheries and ecotourism benefits (Sala & Giakoumi).

title: SDG 14: Protecting half of the ocean?
keyFindings: SDG 14 aims to conserve and sustainably use oceans, but lacks a clear plan for achievement. Only 4% of the ocean is protected, and just 2% is fully safeguarded from extractive activities. The authors propose protecting half the ocean while sustainably managing the other half to achieve this goal. They emphasize the ocean's critical role in sustaining life on Earth, the damage caused by human activities, and the need for a comprehensive approach to ocean conservation and sustainable management to fulfill SDG 14.
metaDescription: SDG 14 seeks ocean conservation with only 4% protected now proposing to protect half the ocean while sustainably managing the other half to reach this goal (Sala & Rechberger).

title: The economics of fishing the high seas
keyFindings: This study examines the economic rationale for high-seas fishing, leveraging satellite data and machine learning to track fishing vessels and quantify fishing effort, costs, and benefits. Findings reveal that up to 54% of high-seas fishing would be unprofitable without government subsidies, particularly for deep-sea bottom trawling and fleets with low labor costs. The profitability of high-seas fishing varies by country and fishing type. These results highlight the need for reforms in subsidies and fishery management to ensure sustainable high-seas fishing practices.
metaDescription: High-seas fishing is mostly unprofitable without subsidies especially deep-sea trawling showing a need for subsidy reform and better fishery management (Sala et al).

title: Vertebrate population changes induced by hunting in Amazonian sustainable-use protected areas
organization: Instituto Chico Mendes de Conservação da Biodiversidade
keyFindings: This study investigates the impact of human activity on wildlife in sustainable-use reserves in the Brazilian Amazon. Using 720 camera traps, researchers analyzed factors influencing the abundance, richness, and reproductive rates of 29 mammal and bird species. The proximity to local communities, particularly within 5 km, was the main driver of wildlife declines, though some game species thrived near communities. Community size, urban proximity, and access to aquatic protein also affected species populations. Local protection enhanced species richness. These findings suggest that limiting habitat loss beyond a 5-km radius and implementing targeted game management strategies can improve conservation outcomes.
metaDescription: Proximity to communities drives wildlife declines in Amazon sustainable-use reserves though local protection helps with species richness  (Sampaio et al).

title: Worldwide decline of the entomofauna: A review of its drivers
organization: School of Life & Environmental Sciences, Sydney Institute of Agriculture, The University of Sydney
keyFindings: Insect biodiversity is in global decline, with 40% of species at risk of extinction in the coming decades. A review of 73 studies highlights that Lepidoptera, Hymenoptera, and dung beetles are the most affected terrestrial species, while aquatic groups like Odonata and Ephemeroptera have already suffered major losses. Generalist species are replacing the declining specialists. Key drivers of decline include habitat loss due to agriculture and urbanization, pollution from pesticides and fertilizers, biological factors, and climate change. Urgent changes in agricultural practices, especially reduced pesticide use, and pollution cleanup are needed to reverse these trends and protect essential ecosystem services.
metaDescription: Insect biodiversity is falling with 40% at risk due to habitat loss pollution and climate change. Changes in farming and pollution cleanup are needed (Sanchez-Bayo & Wyckhuys).

title: Soil carbon debt of 12,000 years of human land use
keyFindings: Human agricultural activities have significantly altered soil organic carbon (SOC) levels, creating a large global carbon debt. Using machine learning models and global SOC data, this study estimates a 133 Pg C loss from the top 2 m of soil due to agriculture, with most losses occurring in the last 200 years. Both grazing and cropland contributed equally to SOC losses, with croplands showing higher percent loss but grazing lands contributing slightly more in total. SOC loss hotspots were identified in major cropping and semiarid grazing regions, suggesting specific areas for targeted SOC restoration to mitigate climate change.
metaDescription: Agriculture caused 133 Pg C soil carbon loss with cropland and grazing key contributors. Restoration should target cropping and semiarid grazing hotspots (Sanderman et al).

title: Natural farming through a wide-angle lens
journal: Global Alliance for the Future of Food
keyFindings: This study reveals that transitioning to APCNF (Agroecological Practices for Chemical-Free Natural Farming) leads to lower health risks, with farmers losing fewer working days to illness and incurring lower health costs due to reduced exposure to chemical pesticides. APCNF farms also exhibited higher household dietary diversity and stronger social capital, particularly among smaller farms. Women played a key role in enhancing social cohesion and knowledge sharing. Research highlights that APCNF provides better yields and crop diversity while addressing environmental and social goals. True Cost Accounting (TCA) shows better long-term returns compared to conventional farming, making it a viable climate-resilient model.
metaDescription: Agroecological farming cuts health risks, helps crop diversity, builds social ties, and improves yields with better returns than conventional farming (Sandhu et al).

title: Examining Sport Fans and the Endangered Species Who Represent Their Affiliated Team Mascots
organization: Department of Kinesiology, East Carolina University
keyFindings: This study explored the relationship between sport fans and mascots representing endangered species. It found that highly identified fans were more inclined to learn about their endangered mascots. The research suggests that sport organizations are well-positioned to drive conservation efforts through partnerships and initiatives, leveraging fan engagement to raise awareness and promote environmental stewardship.
metaDescription: The study found fans of endangered species mascots are likelier to learn about them suggesting teams can promote conservation through fan engagement (Sartore-Baldwin & McCullough).

title: Protected areas in the world’s ecoregions: How well connected are they?
keyFindings: This study introduces ProtConn, a global indicator for assessing the connectivity of protected areas (PAs). It quantifies the percentage of connected lands and analyzes movement between protected locations. Findings reveal that 9.3% of the world's land is covered by connected PAs, below the 14.7% global PA coverage, highlighting partial connectivity success. Only a third of ecoregions meet Aichi Targets for well-connected PAs. The study suggests that less strictly managed PAs can enhance connectivity and provides a tool to identify areas needing improvement. The ProtConn data is available in the Digital Observatory for Protected Areas.
metaDescription: This study shows ProtConn a global indicator with 9.3 percent of land protected and connected below 14.7 percent coverage highlighting connectivity gaps (Saura et al).

title:
A Global Energy Transition is well under way
Advancing the Global Renewable Energy Transition:
Highlights of the REN21 Renewables 2017 Global Status Report in Perspective
keyFindings: In 2016, renewable energy expanded globally, especially in developing economies. Declining costs for technologies like solar and wind, along with rising energy demand, contributed to record growth in power capacity, with 62% of new power capacity coming from renewables. Solar PV saw the largest increase. Renewable energy in heating, cooling, and transport grew more slowly, constrained by low fossil fuel prices and limited policy support. Biofuels dominated renewable transport energy, while electrification continued expanding. Renewable energy also employed 9.8 M people, with China leading. Policy initiatives, like the Paris Agreement, indirectly influenced renewable energy markets.
metaDescription: In 2016 renewable energy grew fast with record solar and wind gains while biofuels led transport. Low fossil prices and weak policies slowed heating (Sawin et al).

title: An assessment of the representation of ecosystems in global protected areas using new maps of World Climate Regions and World Ecosystems
keyFindings: Accelerated climate action to limit warming to 1.5°C would reduce renewable energy costs, increase job creation, and improve energy access. It would also lower risks from extreme weather, boost agricultural productivity, and enhance energy independence. Limiting warming to 1.5°C would also reduce global GDP losses compared to higher temperature scenarios and help prevent irreversible environmental damage, including coral reef loss and rising sea levels. Achieving this goal requires collective global action to accelerate the transition to low-carbon technologies, particularly benefiting developing countries.
metaDescription: This study maps 431 ecosystems showing most are underprotected. Only 19 meet the 17 percent target with harsh areas like snow and ice best protected (Sayre et. al).

title: Pursuing the 1.5C Limit: Benefits and Opportunities
keyFindings: This report seeks to determine the benefits and opportunities related to a faster transition to low-carbon sustainable development. Global emissions have essentially not increased since 2013-2014 despite economic growth of greater than 3% per year, showing that decreasing emissions would not harm economic growth.
metaDescription: Fast climate action to limit warming to 1.5°C cuts energy costs creates jobs boosts access lowers weather risks and helps avoid severe environmental damage (M. Mckinnon).

title: Geometry of global protected lands
keyFindings: This study highlights that global expansion of protected areas (PAs) has primarily added small, complex-shaped reserves. One-third of PAs are within 2 km of unprotected areas, while only 0.6% extend beyond 100 km. Developed nations have smaller, fragmented PAs, whereas less-affluent countries have larger, compact ones. Smaller, less-compact PAs are found in critically endangered biomes, posing long-term threats to biodiversity. The findings emphasize the urgent need to consider the spatial geometry of PAs to enhance conservation effectiveness and ensure global environmental sustainability.
metaDescription: Protected areas are mostly small and irregular with a third near unprotected lands. Richer nations have smaller fractured areas; poorer have larger ones (Schauman et al).

title: Trophic rewilding can expand natural climate solutions
organization: School of the Environment, Yale University
keyFindings: This study highlights the importance of incorporating wildlife conservation into natural climate solutions. While current strategies focus on carbon capture in plants, soils, and sediments, they often overlook the significant role animals play in regulating the carbon cycle. Scientific evidence shows that protecting and restoring wild animals and their ecological functions can enhance carbon storage, helping to prevent climate warming beyond 1.5°C. The research calls for a broader approach to climate solutions that includes the conservation of wild animals and their roles in ecosystems.
metaDescription: Protecting wild animals and their roles boosts carbon storage. Current solutions focus on plants and soils but overlook animals' impact (Schmitz et al).

title: Assessment Report on Land Degradation and Restoration
keyFindings: This assessment evaluates global land degradation and restoration trends across regions and land types, examining impacts on biodiversity, ecosystem services, and human well-being. It highlights current knowledge of restoration efforts and options by region, aiming to inform policies that address land degradation and desertification while promoting ecosystem restoration. The report enhances the understanding needed to develop effective strategies for mitigating land degradation and restoring degraded ecosystems.
metaDescription: This assessment reviews global land degradation, its impact on biodiversity, ecosystems, human well-being and explores restoration efforts to guide policies (L. Montanarella).

title: Last continuous grasslands on Earth
organization: Department of Agronomy and Horticulture, University of Nebraska–Lincoln
keyFindings: Grasslands are the most threatened and least protected biome, yet little research has identified remaining intact areas. This study, using WWF and IUCN data, highlights three key findings: only a few large intact grasslands remain; every continent has at least one; and these regions, despite human pressures, are critical for conservation. These grasslands provide essential ecosystem services, help mitigate climate change, support biodiversity, migration pathways, cultural heritage, and livelihoods. Preserving them is vital for global grassland conservation efforts under increasing anthropogenic pressures.
metaDescription: Grasslands are the most endangered and least protected biome. Few large intact areas remain, vital for biodiversity, climate, ecosystems, and livelihoods (Scholtz & Twidwell)

title:
Soil Health and Organic Farming: Understanding and Optimizing the Community
of Soil Life
keyFindings: Soil life underpins farming, sustaining crops and ecosystems. The soil food web transforms organic matter into nutrients, enhancing fertility. Organic farmers nurture soil health through compost, crop rotation, and minimal chemicals. Research confirms biodiverse soil boosts resilience, reduces risks, and supports long-term productivity, guiding sustainable farming practices.
metaDescription: Soil life sustains farming by cycling nutrients, enhancing fertility, and boosting resilience. Organic methods protect microbes for long-term productivity Schonbeck et al).

title: Soil Health and Organic Farming: Nutrient Management for Crops, Soil, and the Environment
keyFindings: Organic farming centers on maintaining healthy, living soil as the basis for plant, animal, and human health. Instead of synthetic fertilizers, organic growers rely on compost, manure, legumes, and natural minerals, promoting soil life to release nutrients gradually. This enhances resilience and reduces pollution and greenhouse gas emissions. However, organic systems face nutrient timing challenges, nitrogen limitations, phosphorus buildup, and yield tradeoffs. Despite progress from USDA research, many organic farmers still prioritize improved nutrient management tools and knowledge. This report aims to guide farmers in adopting effective, science-based practices for better productivity and environmental outcomes.
metaDescription: Organic farming uses compost and natural inputs to build soil health but faces nitrogen limits, phosphorus buildup, timing issues, and yield tradeoffs (Schonbeck et al).

title: Soil Health and Organic Farming: Organic Practices for Climate Mitigation, Adaptation, and Carbon Sequestration
keyFindings: Climate change intensifies droughts, storms, heat waves, and pest pressures, threatening agriculture and food security. It disrupts crop cycles, erodes soil, and reduces organic matter. Key greenhouse gases—carbon dioxide, methane, and nitrous oxide—have sharply increased due to industrial activities. Healthy soils improve resilience and sequester carbon, helping mitigate climate change.
metaDescription: Climate change disrupts farming via heat, storms, pests, and erosion; healthy soils boost resilience and cut emissions through carbon storage (Schonbeck et al).

title: Soil Health and Organic Farming: Weed Management
keyFindings: Weed management is a major challenge in organic farming due to the exclusion of herbicides. Farmers rely on tillage, which can harm soil health by degrading structure, reducing organic matter, and increasing erosion. While reduced-till methods using cover crops align with soil health goals, they often struggle with weed control and yields.
metaDescription: Organic weed control via tillage risks soil health; reduced-till with cover crops aids soil but struggles with weed suppression and yield stability (Schonbeck et al).

title: Ecosystem Services and Poverty Alleviation
keyFindings: This book reviews the connection between ecosystem services and poverty alleviation, focusing on findings from the Ecosystem Services for Poverty Alleviation (ESPA) program. It synthesizes key research from over 120 projects in 50 countries, offering insights into sustainable ecosystem management and its role in achieving poverty reduction and sustainable growth. The book discusses the challenges posed by changing environmental conditions, explores innovative governance and conservation approaches, and highlights the relevance of ESPA’s work for achieving the Sustainable Development Goals. It serves as a valuable resource for researchers and policymakers in ecology and sustainable development.
metaDescription: This book links ecosystem services to poverty reduction, sharing insights from ESPA's work. It explores sustainable management, growth, and global goals (Schreckenberg et al).

title: Abundance, biomass, and distribution of ants on Earth
organization: School of Biological Sciences, The University of Hong Kong
keyFindings: This study addresses the lack of data on the global abundance and distribution of insects, particularly ants. Using data from 489 studies, researchers estimate the total global ant population at nearly 20 × 10¹⁵ individuals, with a biomass of around 12 megatons of dry carbon, exceeding that of wild birds and mammals combined. Ant populations are most concentrated in tropical and subtropical regions, with the highest density in forests and arid regions. These findings emphasize ants' crucial ecological role and highlight gaps in knowledge about their distribution and abundance, offering a baseline for studying environmental impacts on insects.
metaDescription: The global ant population is nearly 20 × 10¹⁵ individuals, with a biomass of 12 megatons, highlighting ants' key ecological role and distribution gaps (Schultheiss et al).

title: Vertebrate biodiversity on indigenous-managed lands in Australia, Brazil, and Canada equals that in protected areas
organization: Department of Forest and Conservation Sciences, University of British Columbia
keyFindings: This study explores how partnerships between Indigenous communities and government agencies in Australia, Brazil, and Canada could help address global biodiversity shortfalls. Indigenous-managed lands were found to be slightly richer in vertebrate species than existing protected areas in all three countries and supported more threatened species in Brazil and Canada. The findings suggest that Indigenous-managed lands host similar biodiversity levels to conventional protected areas. Strengthening Indigenous land management practices can potentially help nations meet international biodiversity conservation targets and address the ongoing biodiversity crisis driven by habitat loss and land conversion.
metaDescription: Indigenous lands in Australia, Brazil, and Canada have similar or higher vertebrate biodiversity than protected areas, helping global conservation efforts (Schuster et al).

title: Soil as Carbon Storehouse: New Weapon in Climate Fight?
keyFindings: This study highlights the critical role of soil carbon in combating climate change and maintaining ecosystem health. Historically, land conversion and habitat loss have released significant amounts of soil carbon into the atmosphere, worsening climate impacts. Scientists are now exploring ways to restore soil carbon through regenerative practices, such as agroforestry, deep-rooted grasses, and Holistic Planned Grazing. These methods can boost carbon storage, improve soil productivity, and enhance resilience to climate stressors.
