Brazil accounted for 1/3 of losses, driven by agriculture and deforestation, while Indonesia and Colombia showed progress in reducing deforestation. Fires and land use change pose ongoing threats globally.
metaDescription: Tropics lost 11.9M ha of forest in 2019, including 3.8M ha of primary forest. Brazil led losses; Indonesia, Colombia showed progress on deforestation (Weisse & Goldman).

title: Wind Power to Spare: The Enormous Energy Potential of Atlantic Offshore Wind
keyFindings: The Atlantic coast, heavily reliant on fossil fuels, is transitioning to renewables, with wind and solar now powering 2 million homes—19 times more than a decade ago. Offshore wind offers immense untapped potential, capable of generating four times the region’s electricity needs. To realize this, strong state policies, environmental safeguards, and infrastructure investments are essential. With proven, affordable technology and 13 projects underway, offshore wind can meet growing demand, cut pollution, and protect public health and wildlife—if backed by decisive action from policymakers.
metaDescription: Offshore wind can power 4× Atlantic states' needs. With strong policies, it offers clean, proven, affordable energy and protects wildlife (Weissman et al).

title: Algae as nutritional and functional food sources: revisiting our understanding
keyFindings: Global demand for algae as functional foods is rising, but challenges remain. Nutritional composition varies by species, region, and season. Key issues include understanding bioavailability, metabolism, and effects of harvesting and processing. Advancing algal science requires research and collaboration to quantify health benefits and optimize their dietary potential.
metaDescription: Algal foods are in demand for health benefits, but challenges include bioavailability, composition variation, and processing effects on nutrition (Wells et al).

title: Action needed to make carbon offsets from forest conservation work for climate change mitigation
organization: Environmental Geography Group, Institute for Environmental Studies (IVM), VU University Amsterdam
keyFindings: Voluntary avoided-deforestation projects often overestimate impact; most fail to significantly reduce deforestation. Revised baseline methods are crucial for accurate attribution, maintaining conservation incentives, and ensuring carbon accounting integrity.
metaDescription: Avoided-deforestation projects often overstate impact; most show minimal effect. Improved baseline methods are vital for conservation and carbon integrity (West et al).

title: Estimation of Carbon Sequestration in a Restored Tallgrass Prairie Ecosystem in Eastern Missouri (PDF)
keyFindings: A study of restored prairies at the Litzsinger Road Ecology Center measured net primary productivity (NPP), soil respiration, and net ecosystem productivity (NEP) in 2013–2014. Results showed the site acted as a carbon sink (NEP: 794 g C/m²/yr; NBP: 403 g C/m²/yr). This highlights restored prairies' potential for reducing atmospheric CO₂.
metaDescription: Restored prairies at Litzsinger Road Ecology Center acted as carbon sinks in 2013–14, highlighting their potential to reduce atmospheric CO₂ emissions (West & Haake).

title: What is the Price of Conservation? A Review of the Status Quo and Recommendations for Improving Cost Reporting
organization: Department of Zoology, University of Cambridge
keyFindings: Wildlife conservation suffers from limited funding, yet only 13.3% of studies report numeric costs. Cost reporting varies by taxa, habitat, and region, with higher rates in the Global South. Improved practices, systematic cost reporting, and better economic tools are essential to maximize biodiversity outcomes and optimize conservation funding.
metaDescription: Conservation funding is limited; only 13.3% of studies report costs. Systematic cost reporting, economic tools are key to maximize biodiversity outcomes (White et al).

title: Air pollution and child health: prescribing clean air
keyFindings: Air pollution poses a major global health threat, especially to children. It causes around 7 million premature deaths annually and cost the world economy over $5 trillion in 2013. Children are particularly vulnerable—93% live in areas exceeding WHO air quality limits. In 2016 alone, air pollution contributed to 543,000 child deaths from respiratory infections. This WHO report urges healthcare professionals to take action, highlighting that over a quarter of under-5 deaths are linked to environmental risks. Addressing child-specific vulnerabilities is critical to combatting this public health crisis.
metaDescription: Air pollution harms child health, causing 543K deaths in 2016. 93% of kids breathe toxic air. Urgent action is needed to protect children (WHO).

title: Model ensembles of ecosystem services fill global certainty and capacity gaps
organization: Net Zero and Resilient Farming, Rothamsted Research
keyFindings: Ecosystem service (ES) sustainability is hindered by capacity and certainty gaps, especially in poorer regions. Global ES model ensembles for five key services improved accuracy by 2–14% and were equitably accurate worldwide. Freely available ensembles and accuracy data aim to support decision-making, reducing gaps and advancing ES sustainability.
metaDescription: Global ecosystem service model ensembles improve accuracy by 2–14% worldwide. Free data support decision-making, reducing gaps and advancing sustainability (Willcock et al).

title: Land cover change and carbon emissions over 100 years in an African biodiversity hotspot
organization: School of Geography, University of Leeds
keyFindings: Agricultural expansion in Tanzania’s Eastern Arc Mountains (1908–2000) caused a 74% forest loss and fivefold cropland increase, releasing 0.9 Pg carbon. Protected areas reduced deforestation by 150% and promoted forest regrowth, storing 4.8 Mg carbon per hectare. Pre-satellite data are vital to understanding long-term land cover trends in the tropics.
metaDescription: From 1908–2000, Tanzania's Eastern Arc Mountains lost 74% of forests, releasing 0.9 Pg carbon. Protected areas reduced deforestation by 150% (Willcock et al).

title: The World of Organic Agriculture
keyFindings: In 2016, the global organic food market hit $89.7 billion, accompanied by a record increase of 7.5 million hectares in organic farmland—totaling 57.8 million hectares. Oceania leads with nearly half (27.3M hectares) of the world’s organic land, followed by Europe (13.5M) and Latin America (7.1M). Growth reflects rising global demand.
metaDescription: In 2016, organic food sales hit $89.7B; farmland grew to 57.8M ha. Oceania leads, followed by Europe and Latin America (Willer & Lernoud).

title: Food in the Anthropocene: the EAT–Lancet Commission on healthy diets from sustainable food systems
keyFindings: Food systems are vital for health and sustainability but now threaten both. Despite sufficient calorie production, 820M lack food, while poor diets drive obesity, non-communicable diseases, and greater mortality risks than unsafe sex or substance use. With environmental limits exceeded by food production, urgent global food system transformation is essential.
metaDescription: Food systems threaten health and sustainability, with 820M underfed and poor diets causing disease. Urgent global transformation is needed for balance (Willett et al).

title: Effects of gray wolf‐induced trophic cascades on ecosystem carbon cycling
organization: Environmental Studies Department, Center for Integrated Spatial Research, University of California
keyFindings: Gray wolves may influence carbon cycling, increasing net ecosystem productivity (NEP) in boreal forests by 24–52 g C·m⁻²·yr⁻¹, but decreasing NEP in grasslands by 30–103 g C·m⁻²·yr⁻¹. If scaled, these effects match carbon fluxes of 6–20M cars yearly, warranting further study of predators’ ecosystem carbon impacts.
metaDescription: Gray wolves affect carbon cycling, boosting boreal NEP by 24–52 g C·m⁻²·yr⁻¹ and reducing grassland NEP by 30–103 g C·m⁻²·yr⁻¹, matching 6–20M cars' emissions (Wilmers & Schmitz).

title: Half-Earth
keyFindings: Wilson dedicated his life to studying biodiversity, starting with ants and expanding to global conservation efforts. Wilson argues that accelerating habitat loss and species extinction threaten ecological stability. He proposes setting aside half the planet to preserve biodiversity, asserting that only such large-scale conservation can prevent irreversible ecosystem collapse. Wilson emphasizes the need for enhanced scientific knowledge, global stewardship, and a moral shift toward valuing all life. He believes that emerging technologies—biology, nanotechnology, and robotics—could support sustainability if guided responsibly. His message: humanity must do no further harm.
metaDescription: Wilson urges setting aside half the Earth to halt biodiversity loss, citing habitat decline, extinction, and the need for moral and scientific stewardship (E.O. Wilson).

title: Global synthesis of conservation studies reveals the importance of small habitat patches for biodiversity
organization: School of Biosciences, University of Melbourne
keyFindings: Island biogeography theory favors large, connected areas for conservation, often neglecting small, isolated patches. A global analysis of 31 studies reveals these patches are disproportionately vital for biodiversity. Conservation strategies should prioritize restoring and protecting small, isolated habitats and move beyond simplistic applications of island biogeography principles.
metaDescription: Small, isolated habitat patches are vital for biodiversity. Conservation must prioritize their protection, challenging island biogeography applications (Wintle et al).

title: Drought and heat reduce forest carbon uptake
keyFindings: Droughts and heatwaves, worsened by climate change, reduce Europe's forest carbon uptake, weakening its role in offsetting CO₂ emissions. Severe 2022 events highlight risks from recurrent droughts, including tree mortality, fires, and species shifts. Land-atmosphere feedbacks exacerbate these extremes, emphasizing the need for adaptive forest management in a warming climate.
metaDescription: Recurrent droughts and heatwaves reduce Europe's forest carbon uptake, worsen tree mortality, fires, and species shifts, and amplify climate risks (Wolf & Paul-Limoges).

title: Revised methane emissions factors and spatially distributed annual carbon fluxes for global livestock
keyFindings: Livestock significantly impact carbon cycling, with methane emissions underestimated in past inventories. Updated factors for cattle and swine show global livestock methane emissions were 119.1 ± 18.2 Tg in 2011, 11% higher than previous estimates. Livestock methane is a major contributor to rising emissions since 2007, aiding climate assessments and modeling.
metaDescription: Updated data show livestock methane emissions in 2011 were 119.1 Tg, 11% higher than prior estimates, driving recent global methane increases (Wolf et al).

title: Reducing emissions from agriculture to meet the 2C target
organization: CGIAR Research Program on Climate Change, Agriculture and Food Security (CCAFS)
keyFindings: The Paris Agreement targets a 1 GtCO₂e/year reduction in agricultural emissions by 2030 for a 2°C limit, yet current pathways achieve only 21–40%. Transformative technologies, policies, and soil carbon strategies are needed to close the gap, as excluding agriculture raises costs or undermines the 2°C goal.
metaDescription: Agriculture must cut 1 GtCO₂e/year by 2030 for 2°C warming; current methods achieve 21–40%. Transformative tech, soil carbon, and policies are vital (Wollenberg et al).

title: Tropical forests and climate change: the latest science (PDF)
keyFindings: Forests play a crucial role in reducing greenhouse gases by avoiding emissions from deforestation and enhancing carbon sequestration. Conservation, restoration, and improved management of tropical forests, mangroves, and peatlands could provide 23% of cost-effective climate mitigation by 2030. Deforestation significantly impacts climate, increasing local temperatures, disrupting water cycles, and threatening agriculture globally.
metaDescription: Forests curb emissions, store carbon, and offer 23% of cost-effective mitigation by 2030. Deforestation disrupts climates and threatens agriculture (Wolsin & Harris).

title: Frontiers in alley cropping: Transformative solutions for temperate agriculture
keyFindings: Annual row crops harm the environment, emitting greenhouse gases. Alley cropping (AC), integrating trees with crops, offers a sustainable solution. AC mitigates climate change through reduced emissions, overyielding, and resilience to weather extremes. Diversifying tree species and expanding tree crops for food can amplify its ecological and economic benefits, supporting widespread adoption.
metaDescription: Alley cropping integrates trees with crops, reducing emissions, boosting yields, enhancing resilience, and offering diverse ecological benefits (Wolz et al).

title: Alley cropping: Global patterns of species composition and function
keyFindings: Alley cropping, integrating trees and crops, offers economic and ecological benefits. Research over 35 years analyzed 1,244 studies from 77 countries, revealing diverse systems with 410 tree and 276 crop species. However, functional diversity remains limited. Future research should focus on tree diversity, tree crops for food, perennial crops, and facilitative tree functions.
metaDescription: Alley cropping integrates diverse trees and crops for ecological and economic gains. Focus on diversity, food crops, perennials, and facilitative trees (Wolz & DeLucia).

title: Sunken Billions: progress and challenges in global marine fisheries
journal: The Sunken Billions Revisited: Progress and Challenges in Global Marine Fisheries
keyFindings: Global marine fisheries face a crisis, with 90% overfished or fully fished, causing $83B in annual economic losses. Reducing overfishing allows fish stocks to recover, increasing sustainable economic yields. Achieving this requires coordinated reforms. *The Sunken Billions Revisited* builds on a 2009 study, offering deeper regional insights for solutions.
metaDescription: 90% of marine fisheries are overfished, losing $83B yearly. Recovery via reforms and sustainable fishing can boost fish stocks and economic yields (World Bank).

title: Water for our future
keyFindings: Multisector partnerships are vital for sustainable water management, requiring trust and respect for diverse priorities. Shifting focus from projects to services ensures long-term functionality and maintenance. Water must be valued through balanced pricing, infrastructure investment, and accountability. Inclusive planning, especially with women and marginalized communities, is essential. Farmers, as major water users, must adopt responsible practices to minimize waste. Outdated policies need reform, integrating water conservation and demand management. Infrastructure improvements reduce inefficiencies, and targeted storytelling engages diverse stakeholders, highlighting water's importance to their goals.
metaDescription: Water solutions need partnerships, inclusive planning, reforms, infrastructure updates, fair pricing, farmer stewardship, and clear communication (World Water Council).

title: Mangrove Restoration Potential: A global map highlighting a critical opportunity
keyFindings: Over the past 50 years, mangrove loss has harmed ecosystems, climate resilience, and livelihoods by reducing carbon storage, coastal protection, and fish stocks. While restoration is possible, efforts have often been fragmented and unsuccessful. A new global initiative maps mangrove restoration potential, offering a vital tool to guide effective, data-driven restoration policies and investments.
metaDescription: Mangrove loss harms climate, coasts, and fisheries. A global map now identifies where to restore them, guiding effective, data-driven action (Worthington & Spalding).

title: Atlas of Forest and Landscape Restoration Opportunities
keyFindings: Deforestation has cleared 30% of forests and degraded 20%, but restoration of over 2B hectares offers immense benefits. Restored lands enhance biodiversity, livelihoods, soil fertility, and carbon sequestration. Effective restoration includes stakeholder engagement, whole-landscape approaches, and diverse strategies. Global partnerships drive efforts to achieve climate, biodiversity, and livelihood goals.
metaDescription: Restoring 2B hectares of degraded land boost biodiversity, livelihoods, and carbon storage. Global efforts focus on landscape and stakeholder collaboration (Minnemeyer et al).

title: Rainforest-initiated wet season onset over the southern Amazon
organization: Department of Earth System Science, Tsinghua University
keyFindings: Amazon rainforest transpiration drives shallow convection, moistening and destabilizing the atmosphere, enabling early wet season rain 2–3 months before the ITCZ. This shallow convection moisture pump is influenced by late dry season aerosols, highlighting how land-atmosphere interactions and deforestation extend dry seasons, increasing drought vulnerability.
metaDescription: Amazon transpiration drives early wet season rain via shallow convection. Deforestation and aerosols disrupt this, extending dry seasons and drought risk (Wright et al).

title: Global warming overshoots increase risks of climate tipping cascades in a network model
organization: Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research
keyFindings: Current policies may lead to temporary overshoot of the Paris climate targets, risking critical thresholds for tipping elements like the Greenland Ice Sheet and Amazon rainforest. Overshoots increase tipping risks by up to 72%, even if temperatures later stabilize. Minimizing overshoots and stabilizing temperatures at current levels are crucial to avoid high-end climate risks.
metaDescription: Overshooting Paris targets raises tipping risks by 72%, threatening ecosystems like Greenland Ice Sheet. Stabilizing temperatures is crucial to avoid risks (Wunderling et al).

title:
Living Blue Planet Report: Species, habitats and
human well-being
keyFindings: Nearly 3B people depend on fish for protein, with fisheries supporting 10-12% of livelihoods globally. However, marine ecosystems face critical threats: fish populations have halved since 1970, coral reefs lost over 50% in 30 years, and 29% of fisheries are overfished. Rising ocean temperatures and pollution worsen the crisis. Expanding marine protected areas to 30% could boost economic benefits by $920B by 2050.
metaDescription: 3B rely on fish, but stocks are halved, reefs lost 50%, and 29% of fisheries overfished. Protecting 30% of oceans could add $920B by 2050 (WWF).

title: Living Planet Report 2018: Aiming higher
keyFindings: Human activity has driven rapid planetary change, ushering in the Anthropocene, where biodiversity and natural systems are declining at alarming rates. The "Great Acceleration" has boosted health and wealth unequally and at great ecological cost. Despite global agreements, current actions only slow the decline. The Living Planet Report 2018 urges urgent action, advocating an international deal to reverse biodiversity loss, address climate change, and ensure sustainable development. As the first generation fully aware of nature's value and risks, and perhaps the last with the power to act, we face a critical moment to secure a sustainable future.
metaDescription: Human activity drives biodiversity loss despite global efforts. Urgent action is needed to reverse decline, combat climate change to ensure sustainability (Barrett et al).

title: Nature Restoration Missing Piece in EU Climate action Puzzle
keyFindings: The EU nature restoration law could address biodiversity loss and climate change by restoring habitats to sequester 84 MtC annually, matching Spain’s emissions. Urgent action is needed to restore habitats by 2030, protect carbon-rich areas, and rewet drained soils, cutting emissions by 104 MtCO2. Ambition and enforceability are key.
metaDescription: The EU restoration law can cut 84 MtC annually, restore habitats by 2030, rewet soils to cut 104 MtCO2, and tackle biodiversity and climate crises (WWF).

title: Protecting Blue Corridors Report 2022 — WWF Protecting Whales & Dolphins Initiative
keyFindings: This report highlights threats to whales from fishing, ship strikes, pollution, habitat loss, and climate change. Satellite tracking of 1,000 whales reveals migration risks, with six of 13 species endangered or vulnerable, including the critically endangered North Atlantic right whale. Protecting blue corridors is vital for whale survival, ocean health, and climate benefits, as whales store carbon and contribute to a trillion-dollar ecological value. Enhanced international cooperation, including a high seas treaty, is urgently needed.
metaDescription: Whales face threats from fishing, ship strikes, and climate change. Protecting blue corridors aids survival, ocean health, and carbon storage (Johnson et al).

title: Accuracy Assessment of Global Food Security-Support Analysis Data (GFSAD) Cropland Extent Maps Produced at Three Different Spatial Resolutions
keyFindings: NASA’s MEaSUREs Program developed GFSAD cropland maps at 1km, 250m, and 30m resolutions to enhance global agriculture monitoring. An accuracy assessment using 28,733 samples showed accuracies of 72.3%, 80–98%, and 91.7%, respectively. Regional analyses highlighted map differences across field sizes, recommending specific resolutions for effective monitoring of small, medium, and large fields.
metaDescription: NASA's GFSAD cropland maps at 1km, 250m, 30m aid global agriculture monitoring with up to 91.7% accuracy, tailored for field sizes to optimize mapping (Yadav & Congalton).

title: Soil carbon sequestration accelerated by restoration of grassland biodiversity
organization: Department of Ecology, Evolution, and Behavior, University of Minnesota
keyFindings: Restoring late-successional grassland plant diversity accelerates soil carbon storage on degraded lands. Over 13–22 years, carbon storage rates increase 200% in diverse plantings, exceeding monocultures by 70%. This boost is linked to higher production, root biomass, and diverse species like C4 grasses and legumes, highlighting biodiversity’s role in carbon capture.
metaDescription: Restoring plant diversity on degraded lands boosts soil carbon storage by 200%, driven by higher biomass and diverse species like C4 grasses and legumes (Yang et al).

title: Cost-effective priorities for the expansion of global terrestrial protected areas: Setting post-2020 global and national targets
organization: Institute for National Parks, Tsinghua University
keyFindings: Biodiversity loss demands urgent protected areas (PAs) expansion. A spatial meta-analysis identified cost-effective zones (CEZs), covering 38% of land globally, with only 24% under PAs. To protect CEZs, three targets propose safeguarding 19%, 26%, and 43% of terrestrial areas, guiding biodiversity policies post-2020 for cost-effective conservation.
metaDescription: To tackle biodiversity loss, expand protected areas to cover cost-effective zones (38% globally). Targets propose conserving 19–43% of land post-2020 (Yang et al).

title: Pathways to Parks and Affordable Housing Joint Development (PDF)
journal:
LA THRIVES, Los Angeles Regional Open Space and
Affordable Housing
keyFindings: A framework connects urban greening with affordable housing to address California's housing and climate crises. The Los Angeles Regional Open Space and Affordable Housing collaborative identifies five typologies for integrating housing and open spaces. Public parks can drive multi-benefit projects, building on programs like Affordable Housing and Sustainable Communities and Transformative Climate Communities for equitable and sustainable growth.
metaDescription: Integrating urban greening with affordable housing can tackle California's housing and climate crises, promoting equitable and sustainable growth (Yee et al).

title: Practical measures for sustainable shark fisheries: Lessons learned from an Indonesian targeted shark fishery
keyFindings: Overfishing, driven by international trade, threatens shark survival. Despite protections under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, fisheries management is vital. Data from East Lombok's shark fishery revealed that catch rates depend on gear, season, and fishing grounds. Measures like effort controls, gear restrictions, and seasonal closures can conserve sharks and enhance fishery sustainability globally.
metaDescription: Overfishing threatens sharks despite protections under the Convention on Int'l Trade in Endangered Species. Effort controls and gear limits vital (Yulianto et al).

title: Climate policy implications of nonlinear decline of Arctic land permafrost and other cryosphere elements
organization: Pentland Centre for Sustainability in Business, Lancaster University
keyFindings: Arctic feedbacks, including permafrost carbon release and albedo loss, intensify climate change and economic costs. Using dynamic models, researchers estimate climate damages at $24.8T under 1.5°C, $33.8T under 2°C, and $66.9T under current pledges. Nonlinear Arctic impacts make the 1.5°C target marginally more economically beneficial.
metaDescription: Arctic feedbacks boost climate costs: $24.8T at 1.5°C, $33.8T at 2°C, $66.9T under pledges. Limiting warming to 1.5°C is slightly more cost-effective (Yumashev et al).

title: Can carbon emissions from tropical deforestation drop by 50% in 5 years?
keyFindings: Halving tropical deforestation emissions by 2020 supports the <2°C goal and aligns with the New York Declaration on Forests. From 2001–2013, global emissions averaged 2.27 Gt CO2 annually. Brazil led in emissions and reductions, while Indonesia followed. Achieving this target demands reversing emission trends, conserving forests, and prioritizing sustainable development over resource depletion.
metaDescription: Halving deforestation emissions by 2020 supports <2°C goals. Brazil leads cuts, but global action is key to reversing trends and conserving forests (Zarin et al).

title: A visual analytics framework for conservation planning optimization
organization: School of Computing and Augmented Intelligence, Arizona State University
keyFindings: Currently, 15% of land is protected, but 35% more is needed by 2050 to support planetary resilience. Conservation planning is complex, requiring cost-effective strategies. A new interactive system integrates visualization, analysis, and decision-making, helping planners optimize portfolios under various constraints to balance species, land cover, and human activity priorities.
metaDescription: With 15% of land protected, 35% more is needed by 2050. A new system aids planners in optimizing conservation portfolios under varied constraints (Zhang et al).

title: Global spatially contiguous solar-induced fluorescence (CSIF) dataset using neural networks
organization: Department of Earth and Environmental Engineering, Columbia University
keyFindings: Satellite solar-induced chlorophyll fluorescence (SIF) monitors ecosystem photosynthesis but faces resolution and consistency issues. Using neural networks with MODIS data and OCO-2 SIF, researchers created high-resolution datasets for clear- and all-sky conditions, revealing accurate dynamics and drought sensitivity. These datasets improve understanding of global gross primary production variations across biomes and climates.
metaDescription: Satellite chlorophyll fluorescence tracks photosynthesis but has resolution issues. Neural networks with satellite data improved accuracy (Zang et al).

title: Estimation of methane emissions from the U.S. ammonia fertilizer industry using a mobile sensing approach
keyFindings: Methane, a potent greenhouse gas with 28 times the warming potential of CO₂ over 100 years, is largely produced in landfills via anaerobic decomposition of organic waste. In 2016, U.S. landfill methane emissions reached 107.7 Mt CO₂e; globally, 794 Mt CO₂e in 2005. As the third-largest methane source, landfilling is extensively analyzed in this report, covering gas generation processes, emission models, regional and per capita statistics, and recovery estimates. The study offers key theoretical and empirical insights into landfill methane emissions to inform mitigation strategies.
metaDescription: Landfills are the 3rd largest methane source. Methane is 28× more potent than CO₂. New data/modeling help track and reduce emissions globally (Zhao et al).

title: Glaring gaps in tools to estimate businesses’ biodiversity impacts hinder alignment with the Kunming-Montreal global biodiversity framework
organization: Department of Biological Sciences, National University of Singapore
keyFindings: The Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework urges businesses to measure biodiversity impacts. A gap analysis of biodiversity indices revealed insufficient coverage of key metrics like ecosystem integrity, restoration, and Indigenous knowledge. Aligning indices with the framework is crucial for businesses to effectively disclose impacts and support global biodiversity goals.
metaDescription: The Global Biodiversity Framework needs better-aligned indices; gaps in key metrics hinder businesses from measuring and disclosing biodiversity impacts (Zhu et al).

title: Global Tree Cover and Biomass Carbon on Agricultural Land: The contribution of agroforestry to global and national carbon budgets
organization: Key Laboratory for Plant Diversity and Biogeography of East Asia (KLPB), Kunming Institute of Botany, Chinese Academy of Science
keyFindings: Agroforestry and tree cover on farms play a vital role in carbon sequestration but are underrepresented in carbon accounting. By 2010, 43% of global farmland had 10% tree cover, increasing by 3.7% from 2000–2010, adding over 2 PgC. Regional variations highlight Brazil, Indonesia, China, and India as key contributors to gains.
metaDescription: Agroforestry aids carbon storage but is underreported. By 2010, 43% of farmland had 10% tree cover, storing 45.3 PgC, with 3.7% growth since 2000 (Zomer et al).

title: Hidden Land, Hidden Risks? The need for improved corporate reporting of land holdings associated with palm oil production
keyFindings: Zoological Society of London assessed 50 major palm oil firms, finding inconsistent and unclear land use data, masking social and environmental risks. Of 8.6M ha total, 900,000 ha lack stated use, 14% report infrastructure areas, and 30% report unplanted land. Transparency is critical for managing future risks.
metaDescription: ZSL found palm oil firms lack clear land use data, with 900,000 ha unstated, only 14% reporting infrastructure, and 30% unplanted areas (ZSL).

title: The State of Food Security and Nutrition in the World
author1: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
keyFindings: Global hunger rose to 821M in 2017, with 151M stunted children and 50M affected by wasting. Obesity affects 672M adults, coexisting with undernutrition. Climate extremes, conflict, and food insecurity drive malnutrition, eroding food system resilience. Urgent, integrated action is needed to achieve food security goals.
metaDescription: Global hunger rose to 821M in 2017; stunting, wasting, and obesity coexist. Climate change, conflict, and food insecurity worsen malnutrition (FAO).

title: What is Analog Forestry?
keyFindings: Analog Forestry is an ecological restoration method that mimics natural forests to enhance biodiversity and create sustainable, productive landscapes. Inspired by traditional forest gardens, it supports ecosystem functions like water regulation and soil health while providing resources such as food, timber, and medicine. This approach boosts ecological resilience and rural livelihoods.
metaDescription: Analog Forestry mimics natural forests to boost biodiversity, support ecosystems, and enhance rural livelihoods through sustainable resource production (IAFN Secretariat).

title: FAO Statistical Pocketbook: World food and agriculture
keyFindings: 2015 marked a pivotal transition from the Millennium Development Goals to the Sustainable Development Agenda. Significant progress was made, with 72 of 129 monitored countries halving hunger rates. However, robust and timely data remains crucial for monitoring, policymaking, and accountability. Agriculture and food security are highlighted across four areas: resource base, hunger dimensions, food supply, and environmental sustainability. It underscores the interplay between agriculture and climate change, advocating for improved statistical systems to guide global efforts in achieving sustainable development goals.
metaDescription: 2015 marked a shift to new global goals, highlighting progress in reducing hunger, sustainable farming, and the need for accurate data to guide action (FAO).

authors: The Carbon Underground and Regenerative Agriculture Initiative
title: What is Regenerative Agriculture?
author1: The Carbon Underground and Regenerative Agriculture Initiative
keyFindings: Regenerative agriculture is a holistic land management approach that restores soil biodiversity and organic matter, reversing climate change by sequestering carbon and improving water cycles. By enhancing soil health and biota diversity, it boosts crop resilience, water retention, and nutrient density, while mitigating the harmful effects of tillage and chemical fertilizers.
metaDescription: Regenerative agriculture restores soil health, sequesters carbon, boosts biodiversity, improves water cycles, and mitigates harmful farming practices (The Carbon Underground and Regenerative Agriculture Initiative).

title: Global Climate Report
keyFindings: In 2018, global temperatures ranked among the five warmest for most months, making it the fourth warmest year in NOAA's 139-year record. Temperatures were 0.97°C above the pre-industrial average. This marked the 42nd consecutive year with above-average global temperatures. Warming rates have doubled since 1981, with nine of the ten warmest years occurring since 2005.
metaDescription: 2018 was the fourth warmest year, part of 42 years above average, with nine of the ten warmest years since 2005 and rising warming rates (NOAA).

title: Transforming Water-Scarce Cities into Water-Secure Cities through Collaboration
keyFindings: Rising populations, economic growth, and climate change are intensifying pressure on urban water supplies. To secure long-term water resilience, cities need integrated strategies. The World Bank’s Water Scarce Cities Initiative promotes improved water management, fosters a global expert network, and provides technical support to help cities adapt and thrive.
metaDescription: Urban water stress is rising. The World Bank aids cities with resilient, holistic strategies via expert networks and climate-focused water management (World Bank Group).

title: Little Green Data Book 2017
keyFindings: Provides global statistics on agriculture, forests and biodiversity, oceans, energy and emissions, water and sanitation, environment and health, and national accounting aggregates.
metaDescription: Global data covers agriculture, forests, biodiversity, oceans, energy, emissions, water, sanitation, health, environment, and national accounts (World Bank).

title: United States Mid-Century Strategy for Deep Decarbonization
keyFindings: Human activities, particularly CO2 emissions, have raised greenhouse gas levels to 800,000-year highs, driving a 0.8°C rise in global temperatures. Consequences include severe heatwaves, droughts, longer wildfire seasons, and intensified extreme weather. Without action, warming of 2–5°C and sea-level rises of 2–4 feet by 2100 are likely, threatening economies and security. The 2015 Paris Agreement aims to limit warming to below 2°C, with net-zero emissions by mid-century. Nations commit to reviewing targets every five years, and strategies like deep U.S. decarbonization by 2050 align with these goals.
metaDescription: Human-driven CO2 emissions cause severe warming, extreme weather, and rising seas. The Paris Agreement seeks net-zero emissions to limit warming below 2°C (The White House).

title: Deforestation Estimates
keyFindings: Despite advanced satellite monitoring, global deforestation rates remain difficult to quantify due to varying definitions, scales, and methodologies. Recent estimates show variability across regions and forest types. South America is among the regions with the highest forest loss annually, but exact rates differ by source. Standardized, transparent methods are needed for accuracy.
metaDescription: Deforestation data varies by method and definition. South America sees high forest loss, but consistent global estimates remain a challenge (Mongabay).

title: Did you know…? Marine Life / Ocean Facts…
keyFindings: 50-80% of all life exists in the oceans -- an estimated 1M species. Approximately 250,000 of these species are known to science, but 3 times more are waiting to be discovered.
metaDescription: Oceans hold 50–80% of Earth’s life, with 1M species. Only 250,000 are known, while over three times more await discovery (Marine Bio).

title: Goal 14: Conserve and sustainably use the oceans, seas and marine resources
keyFindings: Goal 14 emphasizes conserving and sustainably using oceans, vital for life on Earth. Oceans cover 75% of Earth's surface, hold 97% of its water, and 99% of its living space. They provide food, medicines, biofuels, and act as carbon sinks and storm buffers. Marine pollution, including plastic, threatens ecosystems, while ocean acidification disrupts marine life and food security. Urgent actions include enhanced conservation, funding for ocean science, and addressing climate change to protect this critical, fragile resource.
metaDescription: Oceans sustain life, provide resources, and act as carbon sinks, but pollution and acidification threaten ecosystems, urging conservation and action (United Nations).

title: Global Forest Goals Report 2021
keyFindings: The UN Strategic Plan for Forests 2017–2030 promotes sustainable forest management to support the 2030 Agenda. It includes six Global Forest Goals and 26 voluntary targets, aiming to increase forest area by 3% by 2030. The plan emphasizes cross-sectoral cooperation, political commitment, and forest contributions to poverty eradication, biodiversity, climate resilience, and health. Forests are crucial in mitigating pandemics and achieving sustainable development. Despite progress, deforestation persists, especially in tropical regions. COVID-19 has stressed forest management capacities but also offers an opportunity to adopt greener policies. Urgent, accelerated global action is essential to meet 2030 goals and secure forest-dependent livelihoods.
metaDescription: The United Nations plan aims to increase forest area by 3% by 2030. Forests support sustainability, but deforestation continues—urgent action is neededl (United Nations).

title: Renewables 2015 Global Status Report
keyFindings: In 2014, renewable energy grew despite rising global energy use and falling oil prices. For the first time in 40 years, energy-related carbon emissions stabilized while the economy grew—driven by renewables and energy efficiency. Renewables made up 58.5% of new power capacity, led by wind, solar PV, and hydro. Heating and transport saw slower progress, though biofuels and e-mobility expanded. Supportive policies grew globally, with 164 countries setting renewable targets. Cities and developing nations became key actors. Challenges remain, including fossil fuel subsidies and policy shifts, but renewables are central to climate resilience, energy access, and sustainable development.
metaDescription: In 2014, renewables surged, stabilizing emissions as energy use rose. They made up 58.5% of new power, showing key climate and economic roles (REN21).
